content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far, far away, there lived a king and queen who longed for a child. Year after year, they prayed and hoped, but no child came to fill their castle with laughter.
Then, one day, their wish was granted—a beautiful baby girl was born. The king and queen were overjoyed, and they decided to hold a grand christening to celebrate their precious daughter.
They invited all the fairies in the land to bestow gifts upon the baby princess. There were twelve fairies in total, each one wise and kind.
But alas, the king and queen had only twelve golden plates, and so they could not invite the thirteenth fairy, who was old and lived deep in the forest.
They feared her wrath, for she was known to be bitter and vengeful. On the day of the christening, the twelve fairies arrived, each bringing a magical gift for the princess.
The first fairy gave her the gift of beauty, so that she would grow up to be the most lovely maiden in the land. The second fairy gave her the gift of a sweet voice, like the song of a nightingale.
The third fairy gave her grace, the fourth gave her kindness, the fifth gave her intelligence, and so on, until each fairy had bestowed a wonderful blessing upon the child.
Just as the twelfth fairy was about to speak, the doors of the great hall burst open, and in swept the thirteenth fairy—the one who had not been invited.

Her face was twisted with anger, and her eyes burned like embers. Without a word of greeting, she pointed a gnarled finger at the baby princess and cried, *"When the princess turns fifteen, she shall prick
her finger on the spindle of a spinning wheel and die!"* A gasp filled the hall, and the king and queen wept in despair. But then, the twelfth fairy stepped forward.
She had not yet given her gift, and though she could not undo the curse, she could soften it. *"The princess shall not die,"* she said, *"but instead, she shall fall into a deep sleep that will last
one hundred years. And when the hundred years have passed, a king’s son shall come and awaken her with a kiss."* The king, determined to protect his daughter, ordered that every spinning
wheel in the kingdom be destroyed. He hoped that by doing so, the curse could never come to pass. The years passed, and the princess grew into a kind, beautiful, and graceful young
woman—just as the fairies had foretold. She was beloved by all who knew her, and the kingdom prospered under her parents’ rule.
On the morning of her fifteenth birthday, the princess wandered through the castle, exploring its many rooms and towers. She climbed a narrow staircase that led to an old, forgotten tower.
At the top, she found a small door with a rusty key still in the lock. Curious, she turned the key and pushed the door open. Inside, an old woman sat spinning flax into thread.
The princess had never seen a spinning wheel before, for her father had forbidden them. *"What are you doing?"* she asked, stepping closer.
*"It looks so strange and wonderful!"* The old woman smiled. *"It is a spinning wheel, my dear. Would you like to try?"* The princess reached out her hand, and as soon as her finger touched the
spindle, she pricked it. At that very moment, the curse took hold. The princess collapsed onto the floor, fast asleep. The old woman vanished, for she had been the thirteenth fairy in disguise.
The king and queen, who had been searching for their daughter, rushed to the tower when they heard the commotion.

They found her lying motionless on the floor, and though they wept and called her name, she did not stir. The twelfth fairy appeared then, and with a wave of her wand, she cast a spell over the entire
castle. Every person inside—knights, maidens, cooks, and even the king and queen—fell into a deep sleep, just as the princess had.
Around the castle, a thick hedge of thorns began to grow, twisting and turning until it formed an impenetrable wall. No one could enter, and no one could leave.
Years passed, and the story of the sleeping princess spread far and wide. Many princes tried to break through the thorny hedge, but none succeeded.
Some were caught in the thorns, others turned back in fear. The castle became a forgotten place, hidden behind its wall of brambles.
One hundred years later, a young prince from a distant land heard the tale of the sleeping beauty. His heart filled with courage and determination. *"I shall be the one to awaken her,"* he declared.
When he reached the hedge of thorns, he found it in full bloom, covered in beautiful roses. As he approached, the thorns parted before him, allowing him to pass unharmed.
Inside the castle, everything was still. The prince walked through the silent halls, where knights stood frozen in place, their swords half-drawn.
He climbed the tower stairs and found the princess lying on the floor, as lovely as the day she had fallen asleep. Her cheeks were rosy, her lips like petals, and her hair shone like gold.
The prince knelt beside her and, with a gentle heart, pressed a kiss to her lips. At that moment, the spell was broken. The princess opened her eyes and smiled.
*"Oh,"* she said, *"I have slept so long!"* The castle came alive once more. The knights sheathed their swords, the maidens stirred, the cooks returned to their kitchens, and the king and queen
awoke, overjoyed to see their daughter safe. The prince and the princess fell in love at once, and soon after, they were married in a grand celebration.
The kingdom rejoiced, and they all lived happily ever after.
